A few notes:
- Having a medicated birth/epidural is not wrong. It does not make you less of a women. Childbirth is NOT the time to be a hero.
- Not every Ob/gyn is curt and dismissive. Find a provider that you jive with and feel comfortable with.
- I agree â˜ï¸ acupuncture is great but it will not cure insomnia
- perineum stretching MAY help but there are currently no studies proving that it prevents tearing
- Be wary of getting all of your information from social media. Please please consult with a licensed medical professional

@HealthNut Nutrition I think you're a tad defensive, Nikole. There is some serious hyper-narcissism (not to mention consumerism) going on with pregnancy/newborns these days. I didn't mind your vid. Upvoted. But SCIENCE (btw I'm dual - OHIP is not the Cdn system, it's the Ontario system) is important. I lived on Toronto Island when 2 babies died bc the mothers leaned heavily into home/natural births and it took too long to get them to the hospital.

I couldn't agree more and I appreciate your comment but it's clear you did not watch the video before writing this. I mentioned at the beginning and end of this video how this was MY experience and I'm just sharing what I did and would recommend to a friend. I even said those exact words that "not taking an epidural does NOT make me a hero" I was open to both options depending on how I felt pain level and what was going to make sure both Sage and I were healthy. Yes do your own research always and every pregnancy/delivery is going to be very different and unique. That doesn't mean one can't share what they did as it may help someone else navigate their own journey. There just isn't enough information out there as a mom to be and I am happy to talk about it as much as I can to support other women.

I saw on your birth plan that you said no to eye drops. Can you please elaborate?

Only really need it of you or partner has certain STDs [gonorrhea,  chlamydia] because it can cause blindness to baby but the antibiotics eye ointment can prevent this. But if you know you and your partner don't have these issues then it is unnecessary but the hospitals give it out as routine [they look at it as an easy thing that can prevent something serious + also sometimes partners have cheated and aren't aware they carry these stds]
